ðŸŽ§ Introduction to Unit 2, Session 2: Building Your Professional Profile

Welcome

Welcome to the second session of Unit 2: Building Your Professional Profile! In this session, we will continue exploring how to develop a successful career by focusing on your professional skills and learning to describe them effectively in English.

You will:

  • Listen to real-life situations about professional growth
  • Practise your listening comprehension with workplace-related tasks
  • Learn useful vocabulary and expressions to describe your skills and competencies

ðŸ’¡ What Will You Discover Today?

  • How people adapt and grow professionally
  • Key professional skills and why they matter
  • How to talk about your abilities clearly and confidently

This session combines listening and vocabulary building. First, you will listen and understand professional situations. Then, you will learn how to describe your own skills in English for future tasks and real-world use.

Letâ€™s start!

Get ready to enhance your English and showcase your professional strengths!

âœ¨ Dive in and take your career skills to the next level!

ðŸŽ§ Listening Practice: Challenges at Work

ðŸŽ¯ Introduction

Strong communication skills are essential for professional growth. Being able to talk openly about challenges builds trust, collaboration, and personal development in the workplace. Creating a good video CV is another powerful tool â€” it allows you to present your personality and achievements in a dynamic and memorable way.

Both communication and self-presentation are key to standing out in todayâ€™s competitive job market. Thatâ€™s why, in this section, we will practiseÂ listening skillsÂ that will help you:

Understand professional conversations
Learn useful vocabulary and expressions
Prepare for real-world communication challenges
Listen carefully, take notes, and get ready to build a strong professional profile!

This listening practice helps you understand workplace challenges in fields like logistics, web development, quality control, and system administration. Listen to four audio clips and answer one question per clip to test your comprehension. Use these strategies to listen effectively:

  • Listen for key words: Focus on words like â€œchallenge,â€ â€œproblem,â€ or â€œdifficultâ€ to identify the main idea.
  • Take notes: Jot down important details while listening to help answer questions.
  • Listen twice: Play the audio again to confirm details before answering.

Complete the 4 multiple-choice questions. Click "Check Answers" for feedback. Each correct answer is worth 1 point (4 points total). Aim for 4/4 (100%) to confirm readiness. If you score less than 4, review the audio clips.

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Pay attention to the speakerâ€™s main point in each clip!

ðŸŽ™ï¸ Listening Activity: Multiple Choice (4 items)

Instructions: Listen to each audio clip and choose the best answer for the question. Select the correct option using the radio buttons. Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • Audio 1 â€“ Carla: Logistics Coordinator

1. What is the main challenge Carla faces in her job?


  • Audio 2 â€“ Javier: Web Developer

2. What does Javier find most difficult?

  • Audio 3 â€“ Elena: Quality Technician

3. What is a common problem Elena deals with?

  • Audio 4 â€“ Ahmed: System Administrator

4. What does Ahmed compare his job to?

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Listen carefully for specific details mentioned by each speaker!

ðŸ—£ï¸ Vocabulary â€“ Professional Skills â€“ Unit 2, Session 1

Introduction

To build a strong professional profile, itâ€™s not enough to have technical knowledge. Employers are also looking for people with the right professional skills: the abilities that help you work well with others, adapt to new situations, and solve problems effectively.

In this section, you will learn useful words and expressions to talk about important skills such as communication, teamwork, leadership and adaptability.

ðŸ’¡ Why Is This Important?

  • It helps you describe your strengths in a CV, a job interview or a professional conversation.
  • It prepares you to understand and use real workplace English.
  • It makes your profile more attractive to employers.

Letâ€™s explore the vocabulary you need to succeed!

Master these words to shine in interviews and workplace discussions!

âœ¨ Dive into this vocabulary and boost your professional profile!

Vocabulary Focus â€“ Professional Skills

Introduction

In Unit 2, Session 2, youâ€™re building your professional profile by exploring key skills that make you stand out in the workplace. This Vocabulary Focus introduces hard skills and soft skills, essential for describing your abilities in fields like social integration, logistics, or other vocational areas. Hard skills are specific, technical abilities you learn through training, while soft skills are personal qualities that help you work effectively with others. Mastering this vocabulary will help you communicate your strengths confidently in CVs, interviews, or workplace discussions.

Hard Skills

Hard skills are specific, measurable abilities required for particular jobs or tasks. They are typically learned through education, training, or hands-on experience and are often tied to technical expertise.

  • Accounting: Managing financial records and budgets.
    Example: Preparing balance sheets is a key skill for administration roles.
  • Programming: Writing code for software or websites.
    Example: Knowing Python is essential for an IT developer.
  • Digital Marketing: Using online tools to promote products.
    Example: Creating social media campaigns boosts sales in commerce.
  • Culinary Techniques: Preparing and presenting food.
    Example: Mastering recipes is crucial for a chef in hospitality.
  • Data Analysis: Interpreting data to make decisions.
    Example: Analyzing research results is vital for a biologist.
  • Circuit Design: Creating electrical systems.
    Example: Designing circuits is a core skill for electronics technicians.
  • Anatomy Knowledge: Understanding the human body.
    Example: Chiropractors rely on anatomy to treat patients.
  • Foreign Language Proficiency: Speaking another language fluently.
    Example: Speaking English fluently aids communication in tourism.
  • Graphic Design: Using software like Photoshop for visuals.
    Example: Designing logos is valuable in marketing.

Soft Skills

Soft skills are personal attributes and interpersonal abilities that enhance your performance in any job. They are developed through experience and are crucial for teamwork and adaptability.

  • Adaptability: Adjusting to new situations or changes.
    Example: Being adaptable helps you thrive in a new workplace.
  • Teamwork: Collaborating to achieve common goals.
    Example: Good teamwork speeds up project completion in logistics.
  • Time Management: Organizing tasks to meet deadlines.
    Example: Effective time management balances multiple tasks in administration.
  • Communication Skills: Sharing and listening clearly.
    Example: Strong communication builds trust with clients in commerce.
  • Problem-Solving: Finding solutions to challenges.
    Example: Solving technical issues is key in IT support.
  • Leadership: Guiding teams toward objectives.
    Example: Leadership drives successful projects in business.
  • Flexibility: Being open to new ideas or changes.
    Example: Flexibility keeps you productive during schedule shifts in hospitality.
  • Continuous Learning: Seeking new knowledge.
    Example: Continuous learning keeps skills updated in technology fields.
  • Resilience: Recovering from setbacks.
    Example: Resilience helps you stay positive after a project delay.
  • Networking: Building professional relationships.
    Example: Networking opens job opportunities in marketing.
  • Critical Thinking: Analyzing situations logically.
    Example: Critical thinking improves decision-making in research.
  • Attention to Detail: Ensuring accuracy in tasks.
    Example: Attention to detail prevents errors in quality control.

Skills Across Professions

The following table highlights key hard and soft skills across various professional fields, helping you understand their relevance in different careers.

Professional Family Hard Skills (Technical) Soft Skills (Personal)
Administration and Finance Accounting, Tax calculation, Financial software (e.g., SAP, Excel) Attention to detail, Confidentiality, Time management
Commerce and Marketing Digital marketing, Logistics management, E-commerce platforms Negotiation, Customer service, Communication
Electricity and Electronics Circuit design, PLC programming, System maintenance Problem-solving, Precision, Adaptability
Energy and Water Solar panel installation, Energy audits, Environmental regulations Analytical thinking, Responsibility, Communication
Hospitality and Tourism Culinary techniques, Food safety (HACCP), Hotel management systems Creativity, Stress management, Teamwork
Food Industries Quality control, Machinery operation, Food technology Attention to detail, Organisation, Responsibility
IT and Communications Programming, App development, Network administration Problem-solving, Critical thinking, Flexibility
Installation and Maintenance Mechanical repair, Industrial automation, Safety procedures Responsibility, Precision, Teamwork
Sociocultural Services Educational programme design, Social intervention techniques Empathy, Communication, Conflict resolution
Healthcare Patient care techniques, Medical diagnostics, Anatomy knowledge Empathy, Resilience, Communication
Transport and Logistics Supply chain management, Vehicle maintenance, Route planning Time management, Problem-solving, Teamwork
Use these terms to describe your skills and stand out in your professional field!

âœ¨ Build your vocabulary to shape your career with confidence!

Â Vocabulary Practice: Hard and Soft Skills

ðŸŽ¯ Introduction

This vocabulary practice helps you master hard and soft skills from Unit 2, Session 1, essential for describing your professional abilities in fields like social integration, logistics, or IT. Hard skills are technical, job-specific abilities (e.g., programming), while soft skills are personal qualities (e.g., teamwork). Use these strategies to learn effectively:

  • Categorize skills: Decide if a skill is hard (technical) or soft (interpersonal).
  • Use context clues: Think about how a skill applies to a job to understand its meaning.
  • Practice in sentences: Use skills in workplace scenarios to reinforce learning.

Complete the 18 items across three exercises. Click "Check Answers" for feedback. Each correct answer is worth 1 point (18 points total). Aim for 15 or more (â‰ˆ83%) to confirm readiness. If you score less than 15, review the vocabulary list.

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Think about how each skill applies to a specific job!

â“ Exercise 1: Categorization (6 items)

Instructions: Choose whether each skill is a hard skill or a soft skill. Select from the dropdown. Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 1. Accounting

  • 2. Teamwork

  • 3. Digital Marketing

  • 4. Problem-Solving

  • 5. Circuit Design

  • 6. Communication Skills

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Hard skills are technical; soft skills are interpersonal!

ðŸ”— Exercise 2: Matching (6 items)

Instructions: Match each skill to the workplace scenario where it is most important. Select from the dropdown. Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 7. Preparing a social media campaign

  • 8. Collaborating on a logistics project

  • 9. Writing software for an app

  • 10. Guiding a team to meet deadlines

  • 11. Checking product quality in a factory

  • 12. Interpreting research data

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Think about which skill best fits the job task!

ðŸ“ Exercise 3: Gap-Fill (6 items)

Instructions: Complete each sentence with the correct skill from the vocabulary list. Type the exact skill name (e.g., â€œTime Managementâ€). Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 13. A chef needs strong ___ to create new recipes.

  • 14. ___ helps you meet deadlines in a busy office.

  • 15. A biologist uses ___ to interpret lab results.

  • 16. ___ is crucial for building client relationships in marketing.

  • 17. An IT technician needs ___ to fix software issues.

  • 18. Designing a website logo requires ___.

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Use the vocabulary list to find the right skill!

ðŸ“Š Your Score

Click "Check Answers" in each section to see your score.

ðŸŽ§ Listening Practice: Hard and Soft Skills

ðŸŽ¯ Introduction

This listening practice reinforces hard and soft skills vocabulary from Unit 2, Session 1, through audio-based activities. Youâ€™ll listen to clips explaining skills and their roles in various professions. Use these strategies to listen effectively:

  • Listen for key words: Focus on terms like â€œhard skill,â€ â€œsoft skill,â€ or specific skills (e.g., â€œcodingâ€).
  • Take notes: Jot down skills mentioned to help answer questions.
  • Listen twice: Replay the audio to confirm details.

Complete the 11 items across two exercises. Click "Check Answers" for feedback. Each correct answer is worth 1 point (11 points total). Aim for 9 or more (â‰ˆ82%) to confirm readiness. If you score less than 9, review the audio clips.

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Pay attention to how skills are described in each context!

ðŸ“ Exercise 1: Cloze Activity (6 items)

Instructions: Listen to the audio and fill in the blanks with the correct hard or soft skill. Type the exact word(s) (e.g., â€œCodingâ€). Click "Check Answers" for feedback.



In the world of work, there are two main types of job skills: hard skills and soft skills. Hard skills are specific abilities, like ___ (1) for a programmer or ___ (2) for a chef. They are learned through training or education. Soft skills are personal qualities, like ___ (3), ___ (4), ___ (5), and ___ (6), which help you work well with others.

  • 1.
  • 2.
  • 3.
  • 4.
  • 5.
  • 6.

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Listen for specific skills mentioned in the audio!

â“ Exercise 2: Multiple Choice (5 items)

Instructions: Listen to each audio clip about a profession and choose the correct skill mentioned. Select the correct option using the radio buttons. Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • Biologist

    7. Which soft skill is mentioned for presenting findings?

  • Businesswoman

    8. Which hard skill is mentioned for understanding numbers?

  • Chef

    9. Which soft skill is mentioned for creating new dishes?

  • Teacher

    10. Which soft skill is mentioned for helping students?

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Focus on the specific skill highlighted in each clip!
